direction.raw_text: too, would depart... (beat) ... for boarding school. The dust the Boy has been watching reverses itself. An unseen vehicle comes up the road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But before I could be sent out into the world one very serious matter had to be dealt with. (beat) I was a chronic bedwetter. Since my nanny was the one responsible for my well-being, she did what any responsible Zulu mother would do. She called on the greatest medicine man of her tribe -- Inkosi Inkosikazi. Out of the dust a large black Buick ROADMASTER ROARS up the road and into the yard, scattering chickens and geese, stopping in front of the wide-eyed six-year-old and his tremulous nanny. A huge Zulu jumps out of the front passenger seat and opens the rear door. A moment passes, and then two splayed, cracked feet descend from the car and settle into the dust. INKOSI INKOSIKAZI, 100 years old, small, black, wizened, hair and beard whiter than cotton, a leopard skin draped over his shoulders, a beaded fly switch in one hand, a trussed chicken in the other, exits the car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Legend had it that Inkosi Inkosikazi was the last son of the great Zulu king, Dingaan, who fought both the Boers and the British to a standstill nearly 100 years before, and the night Inkosi Inkosikazi was conceived stars fell from the sky until the sun rose. The circle    complete, the old man sits down opposite the Boy. From     a leather pouch he produces several bones. He throws the    bones on the ground and studies them for a moment. He     begins to wave the fly switch back and forth in front of    the Boy's eyes, chanting low, softly. The Boy's eyes    grow heavy; his lids droop. 5   DREAM - EXT. WATERFALL                                     5 The Boy and the old man are standing above a great waterfall. In the swirling pool far below are ten stepping stones linking one bank to the other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The medicine man instructed me to jump off the falls and climb along the ten stepping stones, counting as I went until I reached dry land. The Boy jumps, cascading down the   falls and into the pond below.  He clambers up the first   rock. It is slippery. He falls off and climbs back on,   buffeted by the spraying water.  He makes his way stone by   stone toward the other side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Even though it was only a dream, I felt as if my struggle to reach dry land was terrifyingly real. The water was like ice, bone- chilling, cold, and as I made my way from one stone to the next I could feel my strength desert me. The progress from one step to the next gets progressively harder as the Boy keeps slipping into the swirling water, coughing and sputtering.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was three rocks in when I ran out of gas. I couldn't pull myself any further. No matter how hard I 5. tried, the current tried harder. I felt myself going under for the last time. The Boy's grip slips off the rock.   He starts to go under.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Inkosi Inkosikazi said the spirit of the great Zulu warriors lived in me. He told me that whenever trouble arose I should return to the waterfall and keep stepping across the rocks until the trouble passed. He said three rocks were enough to conquer my problem with the night water; that I was very brave. He said I was a man for all Africa, bound to her by my spirit, bound by my dreams. (beat) And he let me keep the chicken. The Boy and his nanny watch the car go off in a cloud of dust.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Although I was bound by spirit
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . and dream to Africa, I was bound by heritage and language to the birthplace of my grandparents -- England -- a country I had never seen, but one that was to cause me eminently more problems than bedwetting ever did. CUT TO: 9    EXT. ROAD TO SCHOOL                                        9 A motorcar driving along the road to the school.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The school I   was sent to was attended and   staffed entirely by Afrikaaners,   the oldest of the two white tribes   of Africa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 10   INT. SCHOOL                                                10 The six-year-old walks timorously through the halls, filled with bigger boys -- brash, noisy, hostile. They only speak the "Taal" -- Afrikaans. Over and over they jostle or verbally deride the six-year-old, knocking his books down so that when he bends to pick them up he is kicked in the butt. Or pulling his shirt out from under his jacket and making it hard to move.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I spoke only English. The hated tongue. The language of the enemy who had usurped power and stolen the country through political chicanery and military brutality. A mob of boys, led by a big bully, JAAPIE BOTHA, runs the six-year-old through the bathroom and into the showers, fully clothed. He tries to run out. Jaapie Botha grabs him and throws him back in, holding him with one ham-fisted hand under the shower head and turning the shower on with the other. The six-year-old stands miserable as the stinging water pelts him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: During the Boer War of 1896, 26,000 Boer women and children were herded into detainment camps by the British, where they died like flies from dysentery,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . malaria and black water fever. And it seemed I was destined to shoulder the responsibility for each and every one of those deaths. The six-year-old in his first soccer game receives the ball. He tries to move  upfield, but he is kicked and pushed, the ball taken from him. He gets up gamely to follow the chase, only to be flattened, blindsided by Jaapie Botha.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And no one made this more evident to me than Jaapie Botha, a wheat farmer's son from the Transvaal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 11   INT. DORMITORY                                                11 The six-year-old, asleep, his chicken perched alertly atop the bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The only time I was at peace was when I slept. Inkosi Inkosikazi's chicken proved to be, like his previous owner, a salvation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 12   EXT. REAR OF DORMITORY - DAY                                  12 The Boy builds a small shelter for the CHICKEN, who CLUCKS and forages contentedly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: During the day he would live outside the dorm, happily scarfing down bugs and grubs, secure in a little house I built for him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 13   INT. DORM - NIGHT                                       13 YOUNG MAN (V.O.) And at night he would hop through the window and, perching over my bed, squawking if any intruders came near. 8. Several boys sneak up in the    dark. The CHICKEN begins to CHATTER. The six-year-old     wakes, a shoe in hand ready to throw. The shadows     scatter. The Boy gives the chicken a few grains of corn    and an affectionate scratch behind the ear, and goes back    to sleep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He was my best and only friend.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 14   INT. SCHOOL                                                   14 Boys and faculty running through the halls excitedly, showing newspapers with pictures of Hitler and Chamberlain on the front. Posters and slogans with swastikas are slapped up on walls. Some boys mimic "heiling" to each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sure in time a status quo would have been achieved between me and my schoolmates were it not for the cataclysmic events occurring in that faraway place none of us had ever seen. (beat) Two montjhs after I arrived at the school World War II broke out in Europe. Hitler had vowed to crush the British Empire. The Boers sharpened their swords in anticipation. The six-year-old comes back to his bed in the dorm to find a swastika carved into it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 15   INT. DORMITORY - NIGHT                                        15 The six-year-old sleeps fitfully. There is a MUFFLED SQUAWK. He wakes. A blanket is thrown over his head. CUT TO: 16   INT. DARKENED BASEMENT ROOM                                   16 The Boy is dumped on the floor, the blanket removed. His eyes open in horror. The room is lit by torches. Shadows dance fearfully off two dozen boys with swastika armbands and leather pistol rigs without pistols strapped to their sides. In front of him on a platform Jaapie Botha stands, his shirtsleeves rolled to the shoulder, 9. as another student painfully tattoo-scars his arm with a swastika, using a knife and blue dye. Seeing the six- year-old, Jaapie turns his attention to him and addresses him in Afrikaans.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God has sent Hitler to deliver us from the English bastards who stole our country and killed our people. Heil Hitler! The other boys chorus in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Heil Hitler!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We will swear a blood oath. When Hitler comes we'll rise up and kill the Verdomde Rooineks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A blood oath!    A blood oath! Jaapie bends down and grabs the six-year-old by the shirt front, yanking him up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With your blood. Jaapie slaps the Boy across the mouth three times. Blood flows from his mouth and nose. Jaapie dips his finger in the blood and smears it across his new tattoo. He holds up his bloodied fingers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We swear allegiance to Adolf Hitler. Heil Hitler!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We swear allegiance to Adolf Hitler. Heil Hitler!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Death to all Englishmen in South Africa. Heil Hitler! The chorus repeats.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God bless the fatherland.    Heil Hitler! The voices come back to him stronger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Heil Hitler! Jaapie grabs the six-year-old again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: See what we have in store for you when Hitler comes, Rooinek. Hoy! He gives a command. The boys at the far end of the room part. The six-year-old's eyes open in terror. 17   HIS POV                                                       17 20 feet away Inkosi Inkosikazi's chicken, his chicken, is hung from a rafter upside down, haplessly flapping against his bonds. 18   BACK TO SCENE                                                 18 BOY No! But before he gets two steps towards the chicken he is gang-tackled and held. Jaapie picks up a sling and a rock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For crimes committed against the whole Boer people. I, Jaapie Botha, the judge and Uberfuhrer, sentence you and your Rooinek kaffir chicken to death. Heil Hiter.!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Heil Hitler! Jaapie starts to swing the sling around and around.     The six-year-old struggles to get free.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Heil Hitler!   Heil Hitler! The SLING WHISTLES through the air, faster and faster.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No! Jaapie releases the stone. It flies true, catching the SQUAWKING, struggling CHICKEN flush in the chest. The flapping stops as blood soaks through feathers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Jaapie flings his hand forward, victorious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Heil Hitler!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Heil Hitler! The Boy takes the opportunity to break loose. He rushes Jaapie, whose arm is outstretched, putting him off balance. The Boy catches him low, driving his head into Jaapie's exposed stomach. Jaapie falls back and gets the knife used for his tattooing right in his ass. Jaapie Botha bellows like an enraged bull as he grabs futiley for the embedded blade. His cohorts laugh, thinking it tremendously funny, until Jaapie removes the knife and turns with it, dripping his own blood, his eyes murderous. The laughter dies. Jaapie's breath comes hard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hang him up! A few boys protest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jaapie!   No! But Botha is murderous, intent on revenge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hang him! He waves the bloody knife in the air. Three boys grab the six-year-old and drag him to where the chicken is hanging. Two more boys throw a rope over the same rafter. Others bind the struggling boy, trussing his hands to his sides.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You will pay for the deaths of our grandfathers and grandmothers, our aunts and uncles. All Rooineks will pay and you will be first. Pull! The boys who tied the rope now yank it over the rafter. The six-year-old is hoisted up until he is eye-level with the chicken.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the name of Adolf Hitler and the fatherland, I sentence you to die, Verdomde Rooinek.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kill him!   Kill him!   Kill him! Jaapie swings the sling overhead, faster and faster. 19   ANGLE ON SIX-YEAR-OLD                                         19 He watches as Jaapie bears down. As Jaapie is about to let the rock fly the door to the room opens and two STAFF MEMBERS burst in, surprising in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's this? The rock flies from the sling, but Jaapie's attention is diverted. His aim is off. The rock grazes the boy above the eye. He loses consciousness. The scene FADES TO BLACK. FADE IN: 20   INT. ST. JOHN'S STUDY - DAY                                   20 Prince of Wales School, 1950. PK, 17     going on 18, well- built, intense, clear-eyed, handsome,    stands in front of a seminar and continues reading to 10    students, honor students, Headmaster St. John's chosen    few. St. John, with the demeanor of an Oxford don and    a mane of snowy white hair that reaches his shoulders,    sits off to the side, listening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I came to after being unconscious for two days, the rock missing my eye by half an inch. After a week in hospital it was decided I'd be sent to my grandfather's house in the English town of Barberton, at least until passions at school cooled. Jaapie Botha was expelled; sent home to his family's farm in disgrace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And so the first recorded South African casualty of Hitler's insanity was not a Boer, nor a Rooinek, but a tatter-feathered, half-bald kaffir chicken. PK finishes. The end of class BELL RINGS. Offstage, other classrooms are exiting into the common hall, but no one in St. John's study moves. St. John takes his
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . glasses off and wipes the lenses deliberately.   After a long moment he turns to face the class.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Very evocative, yes. Particularly the image of the chicken. Good choice there. St. John rises, lecturing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Any ideology that needs to attack the thing that least threatens it is an ideology that will not outlive its own generation. Inclusion, gentlemen, not exclusion, is the key to survival. (beat) Something our new government should take heed of, eh? His eyes roam from face to face, fixing his point.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Next week we have Mr. Levy who will enlighten us on... MORRIE, a bright-eyed kinetic, speaks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sport and wager in Imperial Rome, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (facetious) Very apt, Mr. Levy. We look forward to the experience. (pause) All right. The boys bolt for the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: P.K. PK approaches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well-written.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've received notice from the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Oxford selection committee. You are to appear before them in three weeks. I assume you'll be reading a piece of your fiction as your presentational.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A word of caution. Contemporary to most of these fellows means the seventeenth century. Try and keep your theme, um, classical, if you know what I mean.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes sir. I will. (beat) Will the scholarship be decided at the same time, sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Money's a different matter. Different committee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Very good, sir. St. John picks up a book and opens the pages. He begins to read. PK takes it as a cue for his dismissal. He goes to exit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And P.K... PK turns at the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good luck tonight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, sir. St. John returns to his book.    PK exits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 21   EXT. HALL                                                 21 Morrie waits in the now nearly-empty hall, taking some money from another boy and making notations in a black book. PK comes up to him. 15.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How we doing? Morrie consults the book.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You win and your dream comes true. You lose, we're back to bread and butter sandwiches till term's end. What'd he want?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My appointement before the Oxford committee came through.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A snap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For a brain like you, maybe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, you'll read one of your pieces, they'll be begging you to attend.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But will they pay for the privilege?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well let's bloody hope so. It'll be a lonely time without you there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Morrie Levy. Is that the voice of sentimentality I hear coming from you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sentimentality my ass. Practicality. Where am I going to find a sure thing like you to make book on at bloody Oxford?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go on. He shoves Morrie playfully out the door and follows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 22   INT. LONG HALLWAY - CLOSEUP - PK AND MORRIE           22 as they walk down the long   hall looking straight ahead. Sweat dapples PK's face.    Both boys are focused on double doors at the end of   the hall. There is the distant MUFFLED sound of a   CROWD CHEERING.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You hear Sutcliffe screwed Bartlett's sister when he stayed with them over holidays?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't believe it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I heard it from Bartlett's own lips. He's selling reservations for next holiday. A pound for one night; three pounds for four.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You register?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For both of us. Took the whole holiday. The CHEERING crowd grows LOUDER the closer they get to the double doors.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You nervous?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Christ! I'm about to have a calf. This bloody Boer gets lucky, we're in the poorhouse. They reach the double doors. Still in CLOSEUP, Morrie turns to face PK for the first time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now remember. We're not here to exhibit our wares. We go in, we do the job, we get out. Right? PK is so focused his eyes seem to bore through the doors. He does not move his head a hair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Morrie and PK draw a deep breath. Together they push open the double doors. Together they stride into a floodlit, fully-packed sports arena and head down the fan-lined aisle to the raised boxing ring in the center. Schoolboys in their respective school blazers, Afrikaan and English, yell, whistle and clap. PK and Morrie, in FULL FRAME, reveal PK in a boxing robe with taped hands, and Morrie with towel and bucket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And at the end of six matches in all weight divisions, the score is Prince of Wales three victories, Helpmakeer three victories. The stands explode with cheers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And now for the final bout to determine which school will win the Johannesburg 1950 public school boxing team championship. In this corner, weighing 140 pounds, standing 5'8", from the Helpmakeer School with a record of
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: : 4   EXT. YARD - NIGHT                                       4 A fire burns bright in the black African night. The Boy sits holding the chicken, close by the fire, while Inkosi Inkosikazi shuffles around him, drawing a circle in the dust with a stick.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 6   EXT. FARMYARD - DAWN                                       6 The fire has gone out. The Boy is still sitting in the circle, the chicken still in his lap. His eyes snap open. The first thing he sees is Inkosi Inkosikazi sitting across from him with a big smile.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 7   EXT. YARD - DAY                                            7 Inkosi Inkosikazi enters the Buick. The Boy and his smiling nanny watch. They Boy still holds the chicken.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 8   EXT. VELDT - DAY                                           8 The Boy sits on a train looking out the window at the veldt and the wildlife moving across in the distance. A sack on his lap moves. The chicken's head pops out. The Boy gives him some kernels of corn and scratches behind his scraggly comb.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: on the year, Jannie Geildenhaus. A huge cheer goes up for JANNIE, muscular, bare-chested, as he dances and shadowboxes for the crowd. PK enters the ring. He stands, robe on, eyes intent on Jannie. When the noise subsides the Announcer continues.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And in this corner, representing the Prince of Wales School, the current Johannesburg Public School welterweight champion, also with a record of 13-0 on the year, also
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pounds, Kid P.K. Now the English schoolboys cheer for their man, but PK does not respond. He barely moves. He raises an arm in bare acknowledgment. His attention stays focused across the ring on his shadowboxing opponent. PK watches Jannie dance closely when a low CHANTING begins from outside the stadium -- African, tribal, mystical harmonies of black voices building until the white voices inside the stadium are stunned to silence. The song carries beautifully in the night. For the first time PK's focus is broken, but not like the others in the audience, who haven't a clue as to what's happening. He has heard this before. This is familiar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . This is for him. A distant knowing flickers in his eyes like a man who has heard the voice of fate whisper his name. Over and over, one phrase is indistinguishable -- the chorus of the song. "Ono  bi shobi ingelosi." The chanting stops as suddenly as it began. A moment passes before the crowd begins to buzz with the phenomenon. The Announcer attempts to bring everyone's attention back to the business at hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We thank the native population for their spirited display of enthusiasm. But now, on to the main event. Fighters to center ring, please. PK, focused again, meets Jannie at the REFEREE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You both know the rules.     No butts, no elbows, no low    blows. First man to score three    knock downs wins. Let's have     a good clean fight. Good luck     to you. The fighters slap leather. PK turns back to his corner when his focus is broken dramatically by a face in the crowd. 23   HIS POV - FRONT ROW - HALF-DOZEN SCHOOLGIRLS               23 sit; one of them MARIA ELIZABETE MARAIS, 17, with honey- blonde hair and lapis-blue eyes, turns her head and engages PK's eyes and his heart. She quickly looks away. But a  connection has been made -- fire passed. 24   PK                                                         24 goes back to his corner and takes off his robe.   Morrie stands, holding PK's mouthpiece.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: First row, third from the left. Find out who she is. Morrie looks down at Maria.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're in a bloody war here, in
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . case you forgot. Let's keep our mind on that, hey? He jams the mouthpiece into PK's mouth as the BELL RINGS. PK turns to an onslaught by Jannie, a real brawler. Jannie's big, overhand rights almost nail PK until he finds his footing and dances away. Jannie comes after him hard, his schoolmates bellowing encouragement. But PK's far superior boxing skills put Jannie at an immed- iate disadvantage. It is a classic battle of a boxer versus a fighter. PK's jabs keep Jannie at an arm's length, until he closes with a combination. Jannie, willing to take three punches to land one, absorbs PK's point scoring combinations and tries to land knockout punches. When he has had enough punishment he lunges into a clinch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Blery Rooinek.     I'll kill you. PK pushes off as Jannie hammers at his kidneys. Backing up, PK repays the compliment with two quick jabs to the face. PK works Jannie, turning him left then right, working the angles, keeping him off balance while he racks up the points. Jannie goes left. As PK chases him that way his eyes fix on something out of the ring. 25   HIS POV - REAR EXIT DOOR - TALL BLACK MAN                   25 with a younger black companion of more average height, the only black faces in a crowd of 2,000 people. 26   BACK TO SCENE                                               26 Their presence distracts    PK for a split second, and in that split second Jannie    seizes the opportunity. He comes across with a big    right hand to PK's jaw. Jannie connects. PK goes down     hard. The crowd goes wild. Morrie leaps up and down    in the corner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get up!     Get up! But PK is seeing double.    He shakes his head, trying to clear it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Up!   Up! 27   PK'S POV - JANNIE                                      27 dancing in his corner, sensing victory, the Ref over
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . him, counting. 28   BACK TO SCENE                                             28 PK forces himself up.   The Ref checks him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay.   Fight. Jannie comes rushing in, banging PK with a series of hard rights, but dropping his left each time he throws one. PK absorbs the punishment as best he can, backing up, dancing away. Jannie is all over him just as the BELL RINGS. Jannie goes back to his corner, triumphant. PK goes back to his and sits down with a blank ex- pression. Morrie goes to work on a small cut over his eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you trying to do, bankrupt us? What happened? PK turns and looks at the two Africans at the rear door. Morrie's eyes follow him, tensing as he sees the two men.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Christ! If they get caught in here they're dead. (beat) What the hell's going on?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, worry about it later. In case you haven't noticed, this Boer bastard is trying to kill you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You see the way he drops his left when he throws the right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah? The BELL RINGS. PK and   Morrie trade a look. Jannie comes rushing over and  throws a big right. PK steps to his own right side and  pops Jannie right over his dropped left hand. He looks at   Morrie again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 29   ANGLE ON MORRIE                                            29 MORRIE Thank you, God. Jannie comes after PK, paying for each big right he throws as PK finds his mark. PK plants one, then two, then three punches on Jannie's face. Finally, frus- trated, Jannie forsakes all pretense of boxing and tries to nail PK with wild, flailing blows. PK bobs and weaves and feints. Jannie's punches grow weary. PK begins to bear down, driving his man back with rapid-fire com- binations until he delivers the coup de grace, a left hook to the heart and a driving right uppercut. Jannie goes down in a heap. The crowd goes wild. The Referee counts him out. Jannie's seconds rush into the ring to lift their fallen fighter. Morrie also rushes in, followed by the Prince of Wales boxing team. They hoist PK up on their shoulders. 30   PK'S POV - MARIA MARAIS                                    30 rising from her seat, and leaving with the other girls. Their eyes meet. Her hint of a smile breaks his heart. She disappears in the crowd. 31   BACK TO SCENE                                              31 PK's eyes rise to the rear exit.   The tall African and his companion have vanished.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here you go, pal. He hands PK the money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're the treasurer of this company. You hold it. Did you find out what I asked for?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uh, listen, P.K. You know in this world there is no greater proponent of sins of the flesh than Morrie Levy. But  do yourself a favor on this one.  Take my advice. Pass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks for the advice.    The information please.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you know who her father is? Professor Daniel Marais.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So?
direction.name: direction

SCHOOL GROUNDS                                        34 PK makes his way through the darkened campus. A few stu- dents and some staff are about. PK hugs the shadows as best he can. CUT TO: 35   EXT. SENIOR COTTAGE                                        35 PK comes up to the cottage where a few girls can be seen through the windows studying at lamplit desks or readying for bed. Other rooms are already dark. PK slips inside the building. CUT TO: 36   INT. BUILDING                                              36 PK moves along the hall looking for room 22. He is about to turn a corner when TWO GIRLS chattering in Afrikaans come down a staircase. PK backs into a 24. darkened room to his left. Still chattering,        the girls disrobe. 37   ANGLE ON PK                                                      37 pressed hard against the inside wall of a stall with a clear view of the proceedings. He holds his breath as one of the girls heads towards his stall. Her girl- friend cautions her.

direction.raw_text: Those are always cold.     Use this one. The girl turns away to another stall just in time. The SHOWERS START. PK allows himself to breathe again. He exits quickly.

dialogue.raw_text: : 39   INT. MARAIS HOUSE                                      39 An ample house. PAN ACROSS a gallery of oil paintings depicting great moments in Boer history -- the Great Trek, an endless progression of oxcarts heading north, the Battle of Blood River against the Zulu armies, the hang- ing of Boer farmers by British regulars. Women and children herded into a detention camp as their farms burn in the background. Boer kommandos sniping at a British column on the veldt. PAN FROM the pictures TO photographs, sepia-toned, his- torical, and DR. DANIEL MARAIS and PK, strolling past the pictures. Marais points to a photo of a young Boer, turn of the century, posed stiffly with a rifle in the slouched hat of a Boer kommando.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: he led a kommando for three years before your people caught him and hung him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My people?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The English.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I consider myself an African, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As do I. As do the Zulu, the Xhosa, the Pongo, the Ndebele. We're all Africans. But all from separate tribes, ay?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Unfortunately.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why do you say that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because it's the whole tribal idea that creates our problems here in South Africa.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The problems of South Africa, my boy, do not come from tribalism. They come from counter-tribalism. From people insisting that natural laws which have been in place and operating since God's creation, should be tampered with. Does the gazelle sleep with the lion? Does the rhino graze with the mouse? The separation of things is not coincidental. Do you think a Zulu wants to see his culture, his sense of identity, replaced by someone else's anymore than I do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, sir. But I don't think he wants being a Zulu to mean he is denied the same rights as everyone else has.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Which is why civilization is defined by the ability to live under the rule of law. Laws define rights.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But do they define justice?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah. Justice. The banner behind which the English marched as they gobbled up a quarter of the world? Justice, my boy, is only relative to who's in charge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And how long they stay in charge is only relative to how well they dispense that justice... (beat) ... with all due respect.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Marais fixes PK with a stare.   PK's eyes meet his evenly, unwavering. Maria enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Papa, would you like coffee in the library or the parlor?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (pleasant) The library, mein leib. Maria smiles at PK and exits.   He leads PK towards the library.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't figure out if you're brave or foolish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why is that, sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You come here to ask for permission to see my daughter. Correct?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And knowing  who I am, what I stand for, do you  think this sort of discussion  is going to put that request in  a favorable light?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought a man of your intellectual reputation wouldn't want his daughter seeing someone who didn't think.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me give you some advice then. You're right. I admire a keen mind.  But intellectual reputation or not, I am first a Marais, a member of the Volk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And if you're trying to impress a member of the Volk with your intellect, don't do it espousing liberal ideas picked up in an English private school.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: These ideas I picked up somewhere else. Marais opens the library door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No doubt from an expert on race relations.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Actually, sir, from an expert on cactus.

direction.raw_text: : 40   EXT. ROCK OUTCROPPING - DAY                                40 A brilliant African sun beats down on the veldt below. On the rock, a seven-year-old PK sits looking somewhat sadly over the landscape. A long shadow covers him. The CLICK of a CAMERA is heard. PK turns, shielding his eyes with his hand against the glare of the sun to a tall, white-haired figure, shirtless, in hiking boots and kneesocks, holding a box camera.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ja. Perfect.    You will excuse me, please. DOC, speaking in German-accented English, moves off from the sun's glare down to PK's level. On his back is a knapsack with a cactus sticking out of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This I do not normally without permission do, ja? But to catch the expression. After all, it is the expression that is important. Ja? Without the expression the human being is just a lump of meat. You have some problems, I think. I am Professor Karl von Vollensteen. Doc clicks his heels together and bows his head slightly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm P.K. He holds out his hand.   Doc takes it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Such a young person with such an
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . old expression. I think we can be friends. Ja? Eighteen-year-old PK narrates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That was how I met Doc, as he insisted I call him. A chance meeting between a directionless seven-year-old boy and an old German professor out collecting cacti on the African bush veldt. (pause) So began my education. Doc and PK walk the veldt across craggy mountain trails, down dry river beds, through the jungle, always collecting cacti and aloe samples, Doc always talking, always explaining.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doc believed the brain had two functions and that the South African public school system unfortunately dealt with only one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The brain, P.K., has two functions. It is the best reference library ever, which is a good thing to have. Ja? But also from it comes original thought. In school you will get all filled up with the facts. Here your brain will learn where to look, how to look, how to think. And then you will have for yourself all the brains that have ever been. Doc and PK sit high up. PK watches the endless animal migration below while Doc points things out across the landscape.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doc knew everything. He had a love of learning. But his real passion was centered around two things -- music and cacti.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . packs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Until he was fifty, Doc had a successful career as a concert pianist all over Europe. On his fiftieth birthday he gave it all up and moved to South Africa. From that point on it was all cactus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 42   EXT. CACTUS GARDEN - DAY                                42 Behind Doc's simple, whitewashed cottage is a magnif- icent cactus and aloe garden filled with the samples Doc has collected for years. PK and Doc plant another specimen. Doc photographs it. PK records its genus in a notebook.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Every specimen Doc found would be carefully photographed and catalogued.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 43   SUNSET                                                       43 Doc an PK walk through the cactus garden.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If God would choose a plant to represent Him, I think He would choose of all plants the cactus. This one plant has all the blessings He tried but failed to give man. It is true. Look. The cactus is humble but not submissive. It grows where no other plant will grow. The sun bakes its back, the wind rips it from cliffs, or drowns it in the dry desert sand. Not a complaint. In good times or bad it will still flower. It protects itself from danger. Doc touches a cactus needle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But it harms no other plant.   It
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . has patience and solitude and modesty. In Mexico there is a cactus that blooms once in a hundred years and then only at night. That is saintliness of the highest order I think. Ja? From cactus comes medicine to heal the wounds of men and little buttons if you eat one you can touch the face of God or stare into the mouth of hell. It is the plant of patience, solitude, love, and madness. Modesty, beauty. Toughness and gentleness. Of all the plants I think it is closest to God. Ja?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doc was a hard man to disagree with. So when he decided I must spend as much time with him to remedy the flaw in my educational environment I didn't argue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 44   INT. GRANDFATHER'S PARLOR                                 44 Shabbily-genteel, Doc sits in his Sunday best, a cup of tea on his lips, talking in earnest to PK's pipe- puffing, also shabbily-genteel grandfather as PK looks on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Appealing to my grandfather's stoic belief in the primacy of European culture in all its forms, Doc offered to instruct me in piano in return for my helping him locate and gather his precious cacti.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 45   INT. DOC'S COTTAGE                                        45 Doc and PK practice on a beautiful Steinway, so grandly out of place in Doc's simple abode.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As a student of music I was never more than adequate, something I suspect Doc knew from the start. It is the love of music that is most important, he would tell me, and I would believe him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CUT TO: 46   EXT. JUNGLE                                               46 Doc and PK wander through the jungle looking for flora.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everything fits, P.K. Nothing is unexplained. Nature is one big chain reaction. Everything depends on everything else. From the smallest to the biggest. Always in life an idea starts small like a tree. Doc shows PK a small tree with an even smaller vine attached to it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This tree can grow so high it can touch the face of the sky. But this little vine can choke it and keep it small. Most people are like these vines. Afraid of new ideas. Afraid to let things grow. Doc rips the vine away from the tree.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Always listen to yourself. Follow your own idea. If you are wrong, so what? You learn something. And with learning you grow stronger. And if you are right at the beginning? An even bigger bonus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 47   EXT. VELDT - DAY                                          47 Doc and PK move alongside the great herds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I roamed the kloofs and ridges, the dry riverbeds and jungle floors with Doc for over a year, learning more than I realize even today. (pause) I also played a lot more 'God Save the King' due to my new musical celebrity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CUT TO: 48   EXT. BARBERTON - DAY                                         48 TRACK THROUGH Barberton, a small town on the low veldt, in all its colonial backwater splendor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Barberton was a very proper English town with a proper square, a wide main street, and the colonials' overblown patriotism for a homeland most people had never seen, hanging in the air like fine dust. Not quite seen, but there nonetheless.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 49   INT. CONCERT HALL                                       49 PK plays "God Save the King" on the stage. The town's population stands -- the men, stoic; the women, dewey- eyed, at patriotic attention. Some people file out -- the men in officers' uniforms of the South African penal system and their wives -- Boers. They exit to the dagger stares and some undertoned hissing and booing from Her Majesty's loyal subjects.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The only Afrikaaners to live in Barberton were sent there to work at the government prison, just outside town. Germany had covertly supported the Boers in their two unsuccessful wars against British rule, supplying food and medical supplies as well as ample stocks of ammunition.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Germany was an old friend, a trusted friend. And in a country where a handshake is a friendship and a friendship a bond for life, as the war in Europe grew fiercer tensions in Barberton heated up. Suspicion was afoot. Spies were everywhere.
direction.name: direction

He hands PK the report card, his displeasure obvious. As they crest the hill the cottage comes INTO VIEW along with a parked Army car and two armed soldiers leaning against it. Seeing Doc and PK, the soldiers smarten up, raising their rifles and advancing. Doc's face grows pale, his lips tight.   PK pulls close to him for support.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Again it begins. The stupidity. Do not be frightened. Doc puts na arm around PK's shoulder, drawing him close, comforting him. One of the soldiers pulls a pair of handcuffs out of his pocket as he advances.

direction.raw_text: Karl von Vollensteen, for the failure to register as an alien during times of war in accordance with His Majesty's government orders to do so, you are hereby sentenced to be confined at Barberton prison for the duration of the war with Germany. At the door a guard touches PK's   shoulder, holding him back. The door opens. Doc goes     through. Just before the door closes he looks back at   PK one last time. The door slams shut. direction.raw_text: Let's just start out nice and easy now. He hits the bell. The fighters circle. PK's opponent starts punching, jabbing, probing. After two feints he comes after PK in earnest. PK steps left and peppers him with three quick blows to the face. Solly's interest is suddenly piqued. Again the fighters circle. Again the opponent sets up with jabs and again he attacks. This time PK dodges, hits him hard and spins him around, hitting him twice more. A smile appears on Solly's face. The opponent, angered now, gets more aggressive. PK keeps bobbing and weaving, sticking and slipping punches. The opponent unloads, banging away at PK with everything he has. PK backs up two steps, then shifts positions. The opponent's momentum carries him into the ropes. As he comes off the ropes PK throws him an eight-punch combination, demolishing his opponent. PK steps back. The opponent sags. Solly hits the bell, clearly excited.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Never I seen someone so young throw an eight-punch combination. Where did you learn such a thing?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In prison, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You trying to be a comedian and a boxer? Mr. Manager, come to my office. We'll talk terms. You, get showered, and see me after. We'll talk training. Solly and Morrie head off toward Solly's office. PK watches them go, a small victorious smile on his face.

VON ZYL'S OFFICE                                     59 The KOMMANDANT, a brusque man with a salt-and-pepper brush cut sits behind his big desk.

Of course to your English town he is a prisoner, a criminal. To us who respect such learning and culture, he is an honored guest.

direction.raw_text: . He hands PK a pass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This pass is good for any time, any day. Would you like to see him now?

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have cleared a little plot behind the cellblock for the cactus. And tomorrow we have the professor's piano moved here. There is not another instrument like it in the territory. Maybe one day the two of you can give a concert for us, hey?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir. Just then the sound of GRUNTING and THWACKING fills the air. PK passes a room set up as a boxing gym. Through a crack in the door he sees a dozen boys being coached by some guards. Some guards are also being coached by a second man. A third man, LIEUTENANT SMIT, oversees the whole training session. PK watches, mesmerized.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You like to box?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir?

direction.raw_text: There must be someone. GEEL PIET comes shuffling over, properly submissive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You teach this boy basics, and you teach him good or I knock your black head flat, you hear?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I teach him best I know, baas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We train every day. First thing in the morning. Miss two trainings, you're gone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, meneer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come tomorrow.     See this old kaffir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, meneer.     Thank you, meneer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lieutenant, a word? The two men step off to the side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't worry, little baas. Little can beat big any day. First with the head, then with the heart. Little defeat big when little is smart. You can remember that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, no. Don't never call me sir. 'Specially in front of the guards.
direction.name: direction

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Piet.   Geel Piet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kaffir.   Towels. Geel Piet assumes his submissive posture again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, baas.    Coming, baas. He winks at PK and shuffles off.     A BELL SOUNDS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 65   EXT. CARNIVAL                                             65 A bell at the top of a strongman's game sounds. A big Boer farmer, mallet in hand, roars in triumph, swinging the mallet again and ringing the bell again. 66   ANGLE ON PK AND MARIA                                     66 walking through the carnival, munching popcorn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You took a big chance talking to my father the way you did.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not really. Going in I was behind on points with him. I'm English. I attend a politically suspect school. I'm a boxer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He likes boxers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All men like boxers. But not for their daughters. So I had to find some way to make an impression. They get on line for the Ferris wheel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You could have picked a more agreeable topic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And made much less of an impression. Talk to someone about their passion. Even if they disagree they'll remember you. It was really the most logical strategy if you think about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you spend hours thinking about how to deal with me, too?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Days.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Know what I think? (beat)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . You're dangerous. Their turn comes to mount the Ferris wheel.         They get into the seat and strap in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When I was little we would go to my grandfather's farm in the high veldt for holiday. The Ferris wheel starts to go up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My father would take    me   to the top of the highest hill    and   we'd play this game, 'What Do    You   See' until we ran out of things    to   see. Do you ever play that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Want to try?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure. The Ferris wheel stops to let more people on.        Johannesburg glitters beyond.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see a forest. It goes      on forever. There are giant      trees which keep getting bigger     and bigger over thousands of     years. Now you. The wheel begins to move a little higher and then stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see little trees growing on the forest floor, learning to grow with the little bit of light the big trees let in. Now you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see the big trees getting bigger, their leaves and branches making one great green umbrella over all of Africa. The wheel stops again at its highest point.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see the sun growing weaker, giving off less light. I see the big trees dying because they cannot live without a lot of light. I see the little trees take over the forest because they learn to adapt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You tell a very good story. Her eyes sparkle, making her irresistible. PK leans forward. Maria turns her face towards him. Her lips part slightly. They kiss tenderly. The CAMERA RISES FROM them TO the star-littered sky twinkling above. The sky goes from black to grey as the CAMERA PANS DOWN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can't    hit you, can't hurt you. Can't    hit you, can't hurt you. Can't    hit you, can't hurt you. That's    it. Good. Good.
direction.name: direction

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You wear out this old man. See? See how it can work? How little beat big?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir.     But when do I get to punch?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You not going to just punch, man. You going to combination. He demonstrates.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One-two. One-two. C'mon.       Now you. One-two. One-two.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . PK does his best to mimic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh do we have     a boxer here. Yes sir. We build      you to eight-punch combination.      The Geel Piet eight. Then you catch     afire. One-two. One-two. Doc appears in the doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How is the next Joe Louis this morning?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Try and hit me. Doc chuckles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.   C'mon. Doc takes a half-hearted swing.     PK bobs expertly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.   Try hard. Doc sets up and swings left, then right.     PK avoids both swings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are amazing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I'm going to learn the Geel Piet eight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, yes, yes. But right now you have to come learn the Beethoven Fifth for one hour so we can get to the cactus before it's too hot to plant. Did you bring her? PK points to a nearby bucket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Parchypodium Namquanium.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excellent. Excellent. We make from you a champion and a brain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (furtive) Excuse me, big baas. But can I talk to the small baas?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course. Geel Piet looks hesitantly from the man to the boy and then begins.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Every day I see you bring the bucket and in the bottom is some tobacco leaf.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It keeps the roots wet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What happens to the leaf after?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A little I use in some water to make a bug spray for the plants.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And the rest we throw away. Geel Piet fidgets.   He drops his head, speaking low.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you leave the pail when you go plant is a problem, small baas?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't understand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is like this. You see how hard the life is for the people here in prison. Only little pleasure they take from this hard life maybe sometimes when no one watching late at night -- a little smoke. Now with the big war in Europe tobacco is plenty hard to get outside. Inside it is gone. We are the forgotten in here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have bunches of leaves at home. I'll bring a whole bucketful tomorrow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, no.   Mustn't do that, little baas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't understand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What Geel Piet means is it can be dangerous. Something the guards might not want the people to have.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's wrong with tobacco? Why wouldn't they want them to have it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's wrong is people whose job it is to punish. After a little while it is all they know how to do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What should I do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is for you to answer. The sound of a TRUNCHEON on METAL turns them to the door where SERGEANT BORMANN, a side of beef with a sadist's eyes, stands, truncheon in hand. He enters the room and circles the trio.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I smell something not right here, ay, kaffir? He pokes Geel Piet with his truncheon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (submissive) No, meneer sergeant. Everything okay here. Bormann swings his truncheon into the back of Geel Piet's knees, buckling the little man to the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't fuckin' believe you. He glares at Doc and PK.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you're up to something I'll find out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Bormann, still eying them suspiciously, exits.     Doc and PK help Geel Piet up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Schweinhund.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, no.  This old kaffir's okay. Sorry to make any trouble, little baas. We  just stick to the boxing now on.  Sorry, sorry. Geel Piet goes hobbling off, picking up towels.     Doc and PK go to exit. At the door PK turns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Geel Piet. Geel Piet turns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I leave my bucket on the side by Doc's toilet when I practice piano. Geel Piet breaks out a smile he usually keeps to himself and exits. PK looks up at Doc who tossles his hair approvingly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: to me you are the champion of the world already. Come. Let us go box now with Mr. Beethoven. PK and Doc exit.

direction.raw_text: Now at the end of the Geel Piet eight you do this... one-two... (he punches the air) One-two-three... the Solly Goldman thirteen. Okay? PK nods. Solly hits the BELL.   The sparring begins.      PK works his way in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's it. That's it. Move him around. Jab jab. Slip slip. Now. PK pours it on, laying in the Geel Piet eight.   Solly is silently counting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And... one-two... one-two-three. PK fires the last three punches like lightning and backs up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's it. That's it. Now work around the defense. Jab jab. The opponent becomes aggressive.   PK starts dancing, slipping punches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How do you get away with this, Mr. G? Why don't they close you down? I mean, there are laws about blacks and white boxing each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In a public match. Not in a gym. Not yet anyway. The Boer is a funny people. Outside the ring the black is not equal. Inside he is. But only in private, not in public. So I keep my mouth shut, the police go a little blind, and that's that. It's a crazy world, huh? A WHISTLE from across the gym draws Solly's attention. He and Morrie turn to his office where his assistant stands with the tall black man from the Schoolboy Championships. Solly's face takes on a serious ex- pression. He rings the bell. He turns to Morrie.
direction.name: direction

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's a good career move. Risk everything to gain nothing. Very sound business sense.

direction.raw_text: Okay.    What's going on?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well why don't you tell me what you do know.

direction.raw_text: There's an African myth about an outsider who comes one day and unites all the tribes into one against their oppressors. They call it the myth of Onoshobishobi Ingelosi -- the tadpole angel. That chanting at the school championships?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I haven't heard it in years. PK begins to disrobe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And how did this honor fall on your broad back?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I told you about bringing tobacco to the prisoners at Barberton? Well after that was going for a while I learned that even though they could send and receive letters, they never did. They couldn't read or write.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So you did it for them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And after that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A clothing program for their families and a food program. One thing sort of led to another.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can see where 'angel' would be an appropriate title. (beat) But it was, uh, this Geel Piet who was really behind all of it, wasn't it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He was very good at pointing things out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Man like that should be running a country, not rotting in prison.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's not in prison anymore. (pause) He's dead. PK steps into the shower pulling the curtain closed.

GYM                                                  72 PK and Morrie exit the locker room. 73   PK'S POV - ACROSS GYM TO MARIA                            73 talking to Solly. direction.raw_text: Do I look that daft?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Morrie's the brains of the operation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He means the bank. Your boyfriend has a great head for literature but none for finance. They exit the staircase. 75   THEIR POV - ACROSS THE WAY - NGUNI                        75 in the shadow of the alley stands, smoking a cigarette.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 76   BACK TO SCENE                                     76 PK (in Zulu) I see you, Nguni.

direction.raw_text: I see you, P.K. They talk across the narrow street.

direction.raw_text: You have heard my request?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.    Why do you make it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A woman has thrown the sacred ox bones. She has made a fire and read the smoke.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What did she read?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That the Onoshobishobi Ingelosi who is a chief must fight the one who one day will be a chief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But it's not true that I'm a chief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who knows what is true and what is not. The legend of Onoshobishobi Ingelosi is very powerful among the people. They see you box the Boer and always you win. They have heard the stories from Barberton. The people live with little hope. They must see if the spirit of the boy still lives in the man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And   if I lose? If the spirit of the   Onoshobishobi Ingelosi does not   exist in me anymore, then what will   they live with?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Less hope.   But still they must
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . see.   It is our way. At that moment a spotlight blinds them. A police car comes up the alley, stopping in front of them. The POLICE exit, threatening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's this here? Maria is gripped by fear.     Morrie is cautious, unmoving.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An old family servant, Officer. From home. We just ran into each other.

direction.raw_text: Papers, man.   Come on, be quick. Nguni reaches into his pocket.

direction.raw_text: Where you coming from?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gym, sir.   I train there.

direction.raw_text: And you?

direction.raw_text: I'm his manager. The Police look at each other and share a laugh.

direction.raw_text: (to Maria) And you're the sparring partner, hey? The Police laugh. Police #2, satisfied Nguni's papers are in order, hands them back.

direction.raw_text: Nguni. Nguni turns.

direction.raw_text: I'll do it. Nguni smiles and disappears into the night.    PK watches him go.

direction.raw_text: I'm scared for you, PK.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Solly's a great teacher. He wouldn't put me in a fight I couldn't handle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I mean about how involved you are with the black people. That scares me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because you don't understand them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No I don't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you did you wouldn't be so scared. You ever have a conversation with a black person?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Besides a servant. Maria's silence is her answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You should sometime.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hate it when you tease me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry. He kisses her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No you're not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes I am. He kisses her again. This time she responds, kissing him back. The kisses become more passionate, touching, feel- ing. The heat in both of them begins to rise when a car passes, its headlights arcing across the tree, startling them out of their passion. They cling to the shadows until the car turns the corner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I better go. They kiss once, lightly. PK boosts her over the wall and waits until she is safely on the other side before run- ning off into the night.

direction.raw_text: 78 The Oxford Board of EXAMINERS, eminent academics all, sit four across at a lecture table, looking absolutely musty with learning. Across from them PK sits, a folder in his lap. One man, PROFESSOR LEWIS, peruses the file in front of him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: According to your submission you have ambitions to be a writer and the welterweight boxing champion of the world. Lewis reads the last sentence with a tinge of amusement in his voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't you   find seeking a career as a pugilist   and reading for a degree at   Oxford a bit, how shall we put it,   intellectually
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . incompatible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lord Byron was a boxer, sir. And I've never heard anyone question his intellectual integrity. One of the other Examiners coughs theatrically to hide his smile. Lewis looks down the table at the man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do not recall Lord Byron actually engaging in matches for money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Actually, sir, there are several recorded instances of Lord Byron engaging in matches for quite large sums of money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Quite right. Yes. In   a letter to his wife Shelley makes mention of just such a thing. For  hundreds of pounds, actually. Lewis has heard enough.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's move along, shall we? As your presentational you've requested to read from a work of your own fiction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, then, let us hope we'll be treated to the stirrings of another Byron. His sarcasm is not lost on PK.   PK ignores it, opens his folder, and begins to read.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Concerto for the Southland and the Death of Geel Piet. (pause) His name was Geel Piet -- yellow Peter. He was a mix of half the blood in Africa -- Dutch, Portuguese, Zulu, Sotha, and who knew what else. His father
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . deserted his mother before he was born. His stepfather threw him out to survive on the streets of Capetown when he was nine. CUT TO: 79   INT. BARBERTON PRISON BOXING RING                              79 Geel Piet is instructing a nine-year-old PK in the Geel Piet eight. Both boy and man are enjoying what they do -- and each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When I met him he had spent forty of his fifty-five years in one South African prison or another. He was a thief, a con man, a black marketeer. As the narration continues, the SCENE FADES TO: 80   TWELVE-YEAR-OLD PK                                             80 with a much better grasp of the Geel Piet eight.      He and Geel Piet seem closer than ever.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He may   even have killed a man or two in   his time. But despite all that he   was one of the kindest, wisest,   most self-effacing persons I ever   knew. He was my teacher; he was   my friend.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 81   INT. PRISON ROOM                                               81 PK sits opposite a black prisoner who talks to him. PK, thirteen years old now, writes what the man says on a piece of paper. When he is finished, he folds it, puts it into an envelope, and hand it to the man. The man smiles, shakes PK's hand profusely, and exits. PK turns to Geel Piet who is on his hands and knees polishing the floor, seemingly part of the surroundings. Geel Piet and PK share a smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Geel Piet bore no  animosity, held no hate. Should   a guard beat him he regarded it as  self-inflicted,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . the result of some carelessness on his part. To survive the system he lived in he became an expert in the art of camouflage, a master of the invisible. In this he strove to be perfect, and in the end it was his quest for perfection that provoked anger from above and killed him. CUT TO: 82   EXT. PRISON CACTUS GARDEN                                82 Quite advanced after five years of planting. PK and Geel Piet are bent over a cactus, transplanting it. A group of prisoners on the way to a hard-labor work task march by. They chant a verse to Onoshobishobi Ingelosi. PK is a little embarrassed by it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know every time they do that I want to jump up and say I'm just a twelve-year-old. I'm not anything else.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To them you are. You are the one who brings the smoke, the one who writes the letters, the one who puts clothes on their children when they are cold. You are Onoshobishobi Ingelosi.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you know that's not true.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who is to say what is true and what is not true, kleine baas. Doc comes running up, excited, waving a newspaper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Allied armies have crossed the Rhine into Germany. It is almost over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's great, isn't it? He turns to Geel Piet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (subdued) Yes, kleine baas.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: : 41   EXT. DOC'S HOUSE                                           41 PK and Doc walk up a steep road toward Doc's house which sits on top of the hill, both carrying cacti-filled
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 52   INT. PK'S ROOM - NIGHT                                     52 Morrie lies in bed, asleep.   PK sits up at his desk, writing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 53   EXT. DOWNTOWN ALLEY - AFTERNOON                            53 The seedy side of town. PK carrying a gym bag and Morrie looking a bit out of place in their school blazers come striding up the alley.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: : 78   INT. OXFORD BOARD OF EXAMINERS ROOM - DAY
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: You are a good    faker, Geel Piet. but you don't    think it's great at all. It means     you lose your star letter writer    and tobacco importer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No matter that, Professor. We always manage here. What pains me most is I lose my boxer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll come back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (adamant) No, kleine baas. You leave this damn place you don't come back never.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Geel Piet, when a painter finishes a work of art he doesn't lose it. He sends it out in the world so everyone can see the genius of his creation. This is what you are going to do. And to celebrate the launch of such a work of art as you have made our boxer here, I have composed an entire concerto -- 'The Concerto for the Southland' -- which it is my intention to play in concert for the prisoners before I leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not possible. The kommandant never allow the people to have such a thing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He'll think it's a concert for him and the brass. But we'll know, ay? And the people will know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He'll never let black be with white here, Doc.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If the black is part of the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . orchestra, like the piano, he will.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But the people have no instruments in this place, big baas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They have their voices. Each tribe a different voice, a different language -- all singing together. It is brilliant, no?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Except the tribes don't trust each other. They don't even talk to each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (crestfallen) Oh. This is correct.    This stupid hatred.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They will do it for you, kleine baas. You are Onoshobishobi Ingelosi. You bring the tobacco. You write the letters. You put clothes on their children's bodies and food in their bellies. All you do is ask and they all sing for you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's right. Wunderbar.    You are the smartest of us all. Geel Piet smiles as he lifts the watering pot to exit.   A truncheon stops him. All turn to Sergeant Bormann.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A kaffir smarter than all of us? You are a strange German, Professor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That little maniac with the moustache in Berlin you admire. He is the strange German. And soon kaput, I hope.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If that's true you'll not be long for this place, eh, Professor?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, Sergeant.    God willing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you, too, little Rooinek.     But you, kaffir, Hitler comes or goes... He takes Geel Piet's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are going to stay with me. He forces Geel Piet's hand closer and closer to a cactus with long thorns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I will find out all your secrets once your friends are gone. One slip... He pushes Geel Piet's hands onto the cactus needle.        Geel Piet does not cry out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have you. He lets go of Geel Piet's hand.     Geel Piet removes it from the cactus, bloodied.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get out of here. Geel Piet takes his watering can and goes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You see, Professor, they are not like us. A white man would scream bloody murder. Doc and PK glare at Bormann.    He smirks and walks away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the weeks went by and the date for the concert grew closer, my life was a whirlwind. PK and Geel Piet appear before various tribal leaders, talking, agreeing, shaking hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Having obtained the cooperation of all the tribal groups, we set about instructing them. Four men from each tribe were taught the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . intricacies of their group's parts. They were the choral leaders responsible for teaching the others. PK and Doc instruct. Doc plays the piano. PK leads the singers. Geel Piet turns the pages for Doc.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At night the prison hummed with the men in their cells practicing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 83   EXT. PRISON TOWER                                         83 Nervous guards patrol as the SOUNDS of the prisoners singing wafts through the air. CUT TO: 84   INT. BOXING ROOM                                               84 Geel Piet instructs PK. P.K. (V.O.) My boxing instruction accelerated as well. It was as if Geel Piet was trying to give me every bit of boxing knowledge he had before we parted. And always from the corners and shadows Bormann watched and waited. Bormann watches PK and Geel Piet from the door of his room, his truncheon beating idly against his leg. CUT TO: 85   INT. RING                                                      85 A photographer sets up a group picture of the boxing squad -- kids and guards. Geel Piet stands off to one side, OUT OF FRAME.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Our boxing squad, the Barberton Blues, won the State Championship with a perfect record. I won at
direction.name: direction
